name: Paris
clues: City of Lights with an iron tower
Home to the world's most famous smile
Baron Haussmann redesigned my boulevards
facts: The Eiffel Tower was initially intended as a temporary structure for the 1889 World's Fair
The Louvre Museum houses over 380,000 objects with only 35,000 on display
Paris has 37 bridges crossing the Seine River
The city has a lesser-known replica of the Statue of Liberty on the Île aux Cygnes

name: Machu Picchu
clues: An ancient citadel hidden in the clouds
Discovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911
Incan emperor's estate reached by a famous trail
facts: Machu Picchu was built around 1450 CE but abandoned a century later during the Spanish conquest
The site contains over 150 buildings, from baths and houses to temples and sanctuaries
The stones used to build the structures fit together so tightly that not even a knife blade can fit between them
Many archaeologists believe it was built as an estate for Emperor Pachacuti

name: Great Barrier Reef
clues: Living structure visible from space
Home to Nemo and thousands of his relatives
Queensland's underwater rainbow
facts: The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system, composed of over 2,900 individual reefs
It stretches for over 2,300 kilometers (1,400 miles) along Australia's eastern coast
The reef is home to more than 1,500 species of fish, 400 types of coral, and 4,000 varieties of mollusk
It's the only living structure visible from space

name: Petra
clues: Rose-red city half as old as time
Carved into sandstone cliffs by the Nabataeans
Indiana Jones found his Holy Grail here
facts: Petra was established as early as 312 BCE as the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom
The site remained unknown to the Western world until 1812 when it was discovered by Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt
Only about 15% of the ancient city has been uncovered; the rest remains buried beneath the sand
The Treasury building (Al-Khazneh) featured in 'Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'

name: Kyoto
clues: Ancient capital with thousands of temples and shrines
Geisha traditions thrive in Gion district
Saved from WWII bombing due to cultural significance
facts: Kyoto served as Japan's capital for over 1,000 years from 794 to 1868
The city has 17 UNESCO World Heritage Sites and over 1,600 Buddhist temples and 400 Shinto shrines
Kyoto was removed from the atomic bomb target list during WWII because of its cultural importance
The Gion district is famous for preserving traditional geisha culture

name: Serengeti National Park
clues: Home to the greatest animal migration on Earth
Endless plains where lions reign
Maasai call it 'the place where the land runs on forever'
facts: The Serengeti hosts the largest terrestrial mammal migration in the world, involving about 1.5 million wildebeest and 200,000 zebras
The park covers an area of 14,750 square kilometers (5,700 square miles)
It's estimated that the Serengeti is home to over 3,000 lions
The ecosystem dates back to at least 4 million years ago

name: Grand Canyon
clues: A colossal chasm carved by the Colorado
Earth's geological history book with pages spanning 2 billion years
Teddy Roosevelt called it 'one sight every American should see'
facts: The Grand Canyon is 277 miles (446 km) long, up to 18 miles (29 km) wide, and attains a depth of over 6,000 feet (1,800 meters)
It took the Colorado River between 5 and 6 million years to carve the canyon
The rock at the bottom of the canyon is approximately 2 billion years old
Despite its size, it's not the deepest or the longest canyon in the world

name: Santorini
clues: Crescent-shaped island with white and blue buildings
Formed from a devastating volcanic eruption around 1600 BCE
Sunset views from Oia are world-famous
facts: Santorini is what remains of an enormous volcanic explosion that destroyed the earliest settlements on the island
Some believe it to be the location of the lost city of Atlantis
The houses are painted white with blue domes specifically to reflect the harsh summer sun
The island's official name is Thira, though Santorini is now more commonly used

name: Victoria Falls
clues: The Smoke That Thunders along the Zambezi
Named for a British queen, known locally as Mosi-oa-Tunya
Twice as high as Niagara and twice as wide as Horseshoe Falls
facts: Victoria Falls is considered the largest waterfall in the world, based on its combined width of 1,708 meters (5,604 feet) and height of 108 meters (354 feet)
During the rainy season, over 500 million cubic meters of water plummet over the edge every minute
The spray from the falls can be seen from up to 50 km (30 miles) away
A naturally formed pool called Devil's Pool sits at the edge of the falls where brave swimmers can look over the precipice

name: Taj Mahal
clues: Marble monument to eternal love in Agra
Shah Jahan's tribute to his favorite wife
Perfect symmetry, except for one royal tomb
facts: The Taj Mahal took approximately 22 years to complete (1631-1653)
More than 20,000 workers and 1,000 elephants were used to build this mausoleum
The white marble changes color throughout the day, appearing pinkish in the morning, white in the evening, and golden at night in moonlight
The Taj Mahal's four minarets were built leaning slightly outward to protect the main structure in case they collapsed

name: Rio de Janeiro
clues: Marvelous city beneath an open-armed Christ
Sugar Loaf mountains meet Copacabana beaches
Carnival capital of the world
facts: The Christ the Redeemer statue is 98 feet (30 meters) tall and has an arm span of 92 feet (28 meters)
Rio was the first South American city to host the Summer Olympics in 2016
The annual Carnival celebration attracts approximately 2 million people per day
Guanabara Bay, where Rio is located, was created by erosion from the Atlantic Ocean

name: Venice
clues: Floating city of canals and bridges
Marco Polo's home with sinking foundations
Carnival masks hide identities in this lagoon city
facts: Venice is built on 118 small islands connected by about 400 bridges
The city has no roads, just canals – including the Grand Canal which snakes through the city in an S-shape
Venice is sinking at a rate of 1-2 millimeters per year
The city's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site that hosts 20 million tourists annually

name: Angkor Wat
clues: Hindu temple that became Buddhist, largest religious monument in the world
Khmer Empire's greatest achievement near Siem Reap
Five lotus-like towers appear on Cambodia's flag
facts: Angkor Wat was built in the early 12th century by King Suryavarman II
The temple is oriented to the west, which is unusual as most Khmer temples face east
The entire complex covers an area of about 400 acres (162 hectares)
The walls of the temple are covered with nearly 2,000 bas-relief figures depicting Hindu mythology and historical events

name: Yellowstone National Park
clues: America's first national park sits on a supervolcano
Old Faithful erupts on a predictable schedule
Home to colorful hot springs and the majority of the world's geysers
facts: Yellowstone became the world's first national park in 1872
The park contains approximately 10,000 geothermal features, including about 500 geysers
Yellowstone Lake is one of the largest high-elevation lakes in North America
The Yellowstone Caldera is the largest supervolcano in North America, with its last major eruption occurring 640,000 years ago

name: Antarctica
clues: Coldest, driest, windiest continent without permanent residents
Penguin paradise surrounded by the Southern Ocean
Scientific outposts on an ice sheet that doubles in size each winter
facts: Antarctica is the fifth-largest continent, covering 14 million square kilometers (5.4 million square miles)
About 90% of the world's ice and 70% of its fresh water are contained in Antarctica
The lowest natural temperature ever recorded on Earth was -89.2°C (-128.6°F) at Vostok Station in Antarctica
There are no native human inhabitants, but 1,000-5,000 researchers live there throughout the year

name: Pyramids of Giza
clues: Tombs for pharaohs guarded by a lion with a human face
Last surviving Wonder of the Ancient World
Three geometric structures that perfectly align with the stars
facts: The Great Pyramid of Giza was built using about 2.3 million stone blocks, each weighing 2.5 to 15 tons
It was the tallest man-made structure for more than 3,800 years
The pyramids were built as tombs for the pharaohs Khufu, Khafre, and Menkaure
Despite common belief, evidence suggests that the pyramids were built by skilled workers, not slaves

name: Bora Bora
clues: Pearl of the Pacific with overwater bungalows
Volcanic island surrounded by a turquoise lagoon
Honeymoon paradise in the Society Islands
facts: Bora Bora is just 6 miles (9.7 km) long and 2.5 miles (4 km) wide
The island is surrounded by a barrier reef and a lagoon, protecting it from the open sea
During World War II, the U.S. chose Bora Bora as a supply base and built an airstrip there
The local name for Bora Bora was Pora Pora, meaning 'first born'

name: Banff National Park
clues: Canada's first national park in the heart of the Rockies
Lake Louise reflects Victoria Glacier's perfect image
Hot springs discovered by railway workers led to its creation
facts: Banff National Park was established in 1885, making it Canada's first national park
The park spans 6,641 square kilometers (2,564 square miles) of mountainous terrain
Lake Louise's distinctive blue-green color comes from rock flour carried in the glacier meltwater
The town of Banff is the highest town in Canada at an elevation of 1,383 meters (4,537 feet)

name: Mount Everest
clues: Earth's highest point above sea level, known as Sagarmatha or Chomolungma
Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay first reached my peak in 1953
The death zone begins at 8,000 meters where oxygen is insufficient for human survival
facts: Mount Everest stands at 29,032 feet (8,849 meters) above sea level
The mountain continues to grow about 4 millimeters (0.16 inches) each year due to geological uplift
Over 300 people have died attempting to climb Everest, with many bodies remaining on the mountain
The first summit by a woman was achieved by Japanese climber Junko Tabei in 1975

name: Reykjavik
clues: World's northernmost capital city powered by geothermal energy
The 'Bay of Smoke' named for its hot springs
Colorful houses beneath the Hallgrimskirkja church
facts: Reykjavik is the world's northernmost capital of a sovereign state
Almost all of Reykjavik's heating and electricity comes from renewable geothermal and hydroelectric power
The city has no mosquitoes due to its climate
The water in Reykjavik is so pure that it's not chlorinated and comes directly from springs

name: Dubai
clues: Desert metropolis with the world's tallest building
City of superlatives with indoor skiing and artificial islands
Pearl diving village transformed by black gold
facts: The Burj Khalifa in Dubai stands at 828 meters (2,717 feet), making it the tallest building in the world
Dubai has the world's largest shopping mall by total area, the Dubai Mall
About 85% of Dubai's population is made up of expatriates
The city transformed from a small fishing village to a global hub in just 50 years after the discovery of oil

name: Chichen Itza
clues: Mayan pyramid where the serpent god descends on the equinox
El Castillo has 365 steps, one for each day of the year
Sacred cenote was used for sacrificial offerings
facts: The main pyramid, El Castillo, was built to align with the sun's position during the spring and fall equinoxes, creating a shadow that looks like a serpent descending the stairs
Chichen Itza was one of the largest Maya cities and was likely one of the mythical great cities referred to in later Mesoamerican literature
The site contains a large ball court where the Maya played a game called pok-ta-pok, with the captain of the losing team sometimes being sacrificed
It was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988

name: Sahara Desert
clues: World's largest hot desert covering most of North Africa
Sea of sand that was once green and lush 6,000 years ago
Tuareg nomads navigate the endless dunes of this arid expanse
facts: The Sahara covers an area of 9.2 million square kilometers (3.6 million square miles), nearly the size of the United States
It spans 11 countries: Algeria, Chad, Egypt, Libya, Mali, Mauritania, Morocco, Niger, Sudan, Tunisia, and Western Sahara
The highest temperature ever recorded in the Sahara was 58°C (136.4°F) in Libya
The desert has experienced shifts between wet and dry periods over millions of years, and was green with lakes and rivers as recently as 6,000 years ago

name: Prague
clues: City of a hundred spires along the Vltava River
Astronomical clock has marked time since 1410
Kafka's birthplace with a castle overlooking a medieval old town
facts: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world, covering 70,000 square meters
The city was largely undamaged by World War II, preserving its historic architecture spanning several periods
The Charles Bridge, completed in 1402, is adorned with 30 baroque statues of saints
The Prague Astronomical Clock, installed in 1410, is the oldest operational astronomical clock in the world

name: Marrakech
clues: Red city with a famous square that comes alive at night
Maze-like medina surrounded by pink-hued walls
Jardin Majorelle's cobalt blue stands out in this ochre metropolis
facts: Marrakech is known as the 'Red City' due to the color of its walls and buildings, which were built using red clay from the surrounding area
Jemaa el-Fnaa square transforms from a market during the day to an entertainment hub with storytellers, musicians, and food vendors at night
The city was founded in 1062 by Abu Bakr ibn Umar, a chieftain and cousin of the Almoravid king Yusuf ibn Tashfin
Jardin Majorelle was owned by fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, who saved it from being turned into a hotel complex

name: Galapagos Islands
clues: Volcanic archipelago where Darwin developed his theory
Giant tortoises roam these Pacific islands
Blue-footed birds dance to attract their mates
facts: The Galapagos Islands consist of 13 major islands, 6 smaller islands, and over 100 islets and rocks
About 97% of the land area is protected as a national park
The islands are home to unique species found nowhere else, including marine iguanas, the flightless cormorant, and the Galapagos penguin
Charles Darwin visited in 1835 and his observations of the islands' wildlife inspired his theory of evolution

name: Saint Petersburg
clues: Northern Venice built on 42 islands connected by 342 bridges
Imperial capital founded by a tsar who wanted a window to Europe
White nights illuminate the Hermitage Museum in summer
facts: St. Petersburg was the capital of Russia for more than 200 years before the government moved to Moscow in 1918
The Hermitage Museum houses over 3 million items, including the world's largest collection of paintings
During the 'White Nights' from mid-May to mid-July, the city experiences nearly round-the-clock daylight
The city was renamed three times: St. Petersburg (1703-1914), Petrograd (1914-1924), and Leningrad (1924-1991) before returning to St. Petersburg

name: Uluru (Ayers Rock)
clues: Sacred red monolith in the heart of the outback
Sandstone giant that changes color at sunset
Ancient inselberg with deep spiritual significance to the Anangu people
facts: Uluru is 348 meters (1,142 feet) high, but most of its bulk is underground
It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site recognized for both its natural and cultural significance
The rock is made of arkose, a type of sandstone rich in the mineral feldspar
Climbing Uluru was officially closed to the public in October 2019 out of respect for the traditional owners, the Anangu people

name: Pamukkale
clues: Cotton Castle of white travertine terraces
Ancient Hierapolis ruins overlook these mineral pools
Calcium carbonate creates a snowy landscape in a warm climate
facts: Pamukkale's terraces are formed by mineral-rich thermal waters flowing down the hillside
The name 'Pamukkale' translates to 'cotton castle' in Turkish
The ancient city of Hierapolis was built on top of the white 'castle'
People have bathed in its pools for thousands of years

name: Fiji
clues: Island nation known as the 'Soft Coral Capital'
Bula!' is the greeting you'll hear everywhere
Over 300 islands and atolls, many uninhabited
facts: Fiji is an archipelago of more than 300 islands and 500 islets
The two major islands, Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, account for 87% of the population
Fiji is known for its friendly people and vibrant culture, including the traditional 'kava' ceremony
The country has a significant Indo-Fijian population, descendants of indentured laborers brought by the British in the 19th century

name: Cairo
clues: City of a Thousand Minarets
Home to the Egyptian Museum of Antiquities
The Nile flows through this bustling metropolis
facts: Cairo is the largest city in Africa and the Middle East.
It is located on the Nile River.
The city's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Cairo is home to the Great Pyramid of Giza and the Sphinx.

name: Amsterdam
clues: City of canals, bicycles, and tulips
Home to Anne Frank's House and the Rijksmuseum
Known for its liberal attitudes and vibrant nightlife
facts: Amsterdam has more than 100 kilometers (62 miles) of canals.
There are more bicycles than people in Amsterdam.
The city is home to many world-renowned museums, including the Van Gogh Museum and the Anne Frank House.
Amsterdam is known for its tolerance and diversity.

name: Barcelona
clues: Gaudi's Sagrada Familia dominates this Catalan city
Las Ramblas street is a hub of activity day and night
Home to FC Barcelona and a passionate football culture
facts: The Sagrada Familia basilica has been under construction since 1882 and is still not finished.
Barcelona is the capital of Catalonia, a region with its own distinct language and culture.
The city hosted the 1992 Summer Olympics.
Barcelona's beaches were created artificially using sand imported from Egypt.

name: Cape Town
clues: Table Mountain overlooks this legislative capital
Robben Island held political prisoners, including Nelson Mandela
Meeting point of two oceans and diverse cultures
facts: Table Mountain is one of the New7Wonders of Nature.
Cape Town is considered the most biodiverse city in the world.
The Cape of Good Hope is a landmark at the southern tip of the Cape Peninsula.
Cape Town is known for its vibrant arts and culture scene, including its colorful Bo-Kaap neighborhood.

name: Ha Long Bay
clues: Bay of Descending Dragons with thousands of limestone karsts
Emerald waters and hidden caves explored by kayak
UNESCO World Heritage Site with legendary origins
facts: Ha Long Bay features over 1,600 islands and islets, most of which are uninhabited.
The bay's name means 'descending dragon' in Vietnamese.
Legend says the islands were created by a dragon sent by the gods to protect Vietnam.
The bay is home to a diverse ecosystem, including many endemic species.

name: Salzburg
clues: Birthplace of Mozart and setting for 'The Sound of Music'
Baroque architecture dominated by Hohensalzburg Fortress
facts: Salzburg is the birthplace of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.
The city is known for its Baroque architecture, including the Hohensalzburg Fortress.
The Sound of Music was filmed in and around Salzburg.
Salzburg is home to the world-famous Salzburg Festival.
